numbered_ace_sentences: 1. This graph measures a relation between parents' income, legacy status, and admissions status at the collegiate level.
2. I noticed a general pattern in the graph.
3. Richer applicants have a greater estimated legacy boost than poorer applicants.
4. Some applicants have parents with an income rank close to 100.
5. For these applicants, the estimated legacy boost is close to 7x.
6. Some applicants have parents with an income rank close to 10.
7. For these applicants, the estimated legacy boost is close to 2x.
8. I wonder whether the legacy boost is greater for an applicant whose parents have a higher income rank.
9. I think that a richer background increases the chance that multiple generations of a family can afford to attend the same college.
10. I noticed another pattern in the graph.
11. Some applicants do not have legacy status.
12. Some of these applicants are on the richer end of the income spectrum.
13. For these applicants, the estimated admissions advantage is lower than for poorer applicants without legacy status.
14. I wonder why this is the case.
15. I wonder what criteria a school uses to determine legacy boost discrepancies.
16. I wonder what processes a school uses to determine legacy boost discrepancies.
17. I wonder whether these criteria vary from college to college.
18. I wonder whether these processes vary from college to college.
19. This topic applies to my community.
20. I recently went through the college admissions process.
21. The concept of legacy advantage is a concern for many people in my community.
22. Legacy advantage can be unfair.
23. A non-legacy applicant can have a profile that is very similar to a legacy applicant.
24. A school can favor a legacy applicant over a non-legacy applicant.
25. My headline for this graph is: Is bias overcoming the college admissions process?
